author: TangerineGroovin

text:
@Natendo64 

FF9 had much more traditional gameplay than FF7 and FF8. 7 and 8 had you assign attribute/ability stuff to characters when 9 made everything simple and each character was unique. I would say that the story of 9 was better than the one in 7 and 8. 10 really is the turning point going downhill since some characters were annoying as well as other aspects, but the battle system was still alright. As for X-2, the ONLY thing I thought was good about that game was the battle system.
author: GameBeatenakaKevinS

text:
@zsybrant 

And those are the obvious reasons I referred to, in case anyone else was wondering what I meant by that statement.
author: GameBeatenakaKevinS

text:
@Masz52 

I played the demo that came with Dragon Quest VIII and I did not like it. It felt too similar to an MMO, which I also hate. Also I did not like that I could control one character at a time. Which is also why I dislike FF13.

text:
The sign of a good game: One day, years ago, I made a friend on the streets just because I was whistling this tune. Now, 15 years later, we're still close as brothers.

text: @bdfan4ever OMG! Thank you so much for pointing out the asinine hatred SE seems to get from nostolgic whores. While I agree they where the best in their golden age on the SNES & PS1, they still make wonderful games. Dissidia, Birth by Sleep and FF13 where amazing to me, Nier was great and is SO underrated. I'd throw in The Third Birthday, even with it's wacky plot, the gameplay is intense and rewarding. SE is the reason to buy a PSP really, along with Peacewalker and playing PS1 games on the go

text: I'll always remember this particular track since it's the first one you hear when the adventure truly starts. I rented this game as soon as it came out and I was blown away by the graphics. I remember the first area where this plays, I'd just have fun running around and jumping, fighting some monsters here and there. It really was a refreshing RPG at the time, and it still is even after many playthroughs.
